title: Install
content:
This topic provides an overview of the installation options and considerations and a To-Do list of tasks before, during, and after the installation of OpenText Service Management. Before you begin, review the information on this page to get an overall picture of your installation journey.  

Always follow the installation instructions and install the latest version of OpenText Service Management. If you have a reason to install an older release, please contact OpenText Service Management Product Management.
It is the customer's responsibility to implement appropriate network security controls in their system. By not implementing appropriate network security controls you may be exposing the system to increased security risks. You understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same. It remains at all times the Customer's sole responsibility to assess its own regulatory and business requirements. OpenText does not represent or warrant that its products comply with any specific legal or regulatory standards applicable to Customer in conducting Customer's business

OpenText SaaS, embedded K8s, managed K8s, or external K8s  

OpenText Service Management is available as an OpenText SaaS solution worldwide; however, should your organization prefer, you can deploy the solution on a supported platform. 

Supported deployment platforms

You can install OpenText Service Management ((also referred to as "Service Management" or "the suite" throughout the documentation) on an existing third-party Kubernetes cluster, either cloud based or on-premises ("external Kubernetes"). If you don't have an existing Kubernetes cluster, you can install OMT together with a built-in Kubernetes cluster on physical or virtual machines in your datacenter ("embedded Kubernetes"). 

K8s distribution type Deployment platform Description
Embedded K8s ITOM OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) Deploy on physical or virtual machines with Kubernetes bundled with ITOM OMT provided by OpenText. See the OpenText OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) section below for more information. 
External K8s (Managed) Amazon Web Services (AWS)  Deploy on AWS with Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) and other cloud native services such as Elastic File Service (EFS) and Relational Database Service (RDS). To learn more, see EKS deployment FAQs.
AWS GovCloud Deploy on AWS GovCloud with Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) and other cloud native services like Elastic File Service (EFS) and Relational Database Service (RDS). To learn more, see EKS deployment FAQs.
Azure Deploy on Azure with Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) and other cloud native services like Azurefile and Azure NetApp Files. To learn more, see AKS deployment FAQs.
Google Cloud Platform (GCP) Deploy on GCP with Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) and other cloud native services like Filestore and Persistent disks. To learn more, see GCP deployment FAQs.
External K8s RedHat OpenShift Deploy on-premises with RedHat OpenShift Kubernetes and on-premises databases and persistent storage.
Bring Your Own Kubernetes (BYOK) Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) certified platforms

Deploy on any CNCF certified platforms along with on-premises databases and persistent storage.

    OpenText OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) 

    OMT provides the necessary tooling for installing and running containerized applications on Kubernetes. OMT has two installation packages: 

    • OMT2xx-xxx-15001-external-K8s.zip:for deployments using an external K8s distribution (package does not include K8s distribution).
    • OMT2xx-xxx-15001-embedded-K8s.zip: for deployments using an embedded K8s distribution 

    Both packages offer a set of capabilities that you can select to install according to your needs: the AppHub, CLI tools, NFS Provisioner (for dynamic volume provisioning), K8s Backup, and more. For more information, see Install OMT on an external K8s and Install OMT with the embedded K8s. 

    For Helm deployments using external K8s, OMT is not mandatory but we highly recommend that you have the OMT CLI tools installed, at a minimum. You can use the OMT CLI tools for tasks such as downloading images, starting and stopping applications. The OMT App Hub is optional if you prefer to use your own deployment management tool. See the Helm installation approach section on this page for considerations about using the OMT AppHub.

    Docker Hub

    The OMT binaries are split and located on the OpenText software download site and Docker Hub. OpenText endeavors to place a maximum number of binaries in Docker Hub. The binaries on the OpenText software download site are required for bootstrapping, and come as a single compressed and digitally signed archive. The remaining OMT binaries and the suite binaries are located in Docker Hub. These binaries come as pre-packaged and digitally signed container images. 

    All of the suite code is hosted in Docker Hub. The container image repositories are private and require authentication (by Docker Hub) and authorization (by OpenText). All of the images are digitally signed.

    Authentication is provided by Docker Hub. Access requires a Docker Hub account. OpenText doesn't create or manage Docker Hub accounts, OpenText only authorizes Docker Hub accounts. Once a Docker Hub account has been created, and with a valid agreement in place with OpenText for suite access, OpenText will authorize access to one or more suite container image repositories. 

    Suite Helm chart

    An ITOM suite or product can be described by a Helm chart. The Helm chart describes the composition of an application and a set of runtime requirements such as volumes for persistent storage and also includes the deployment configuration for Kubernetes. By using the Helm CLI or the AppHub Helm chart installer, customers can deploy the ITOM application or product. During the development cycle, the Helm chart is constructed so that when the development cycle is complete, the new version of the application is described by it. The Helm chart is then provided as a download, and you can feed the downloaded archive into OMT AppHub or the Helm CLI.

    Dynamic vs static volume provisioning

    If a container stops or restarts, all changes made inside the container are lost. To address this, Kubernetes offers persistent storage options in the form  PersistentVolume (PV) and PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC), two API objects:

    • A PV is a piece of storage in the cluster that has been provisioned by an administrator or dynamically provisioned using Storage Classes.
    • A PVC is a request for storage by a cluster component such as a Pod. It can specify a storage class, a size, and access modes, which will help Kubernetes decide which persistent volume to bind it with.

    You can consider PVs as a mapping to a storage volume, for example, an NFS server volume. When you create a PV, the storage volume becomes available in the Kubernetes cluster. To use the storage, the cluster components must create a  PVC. You can think of PVC as an intermediary between the cluster components and the actual storage volume. Kubernetes will then bind the PV to the PVC to make the storage available to the cluster components for use.

    The process flow for a Pod accessing a storage volume such as NFS is as follows: 

    Pod -> PVC -> PV -> Storage Volume (For example, NFS).

    To install the application in the Helm mode, you must create PVs. You can create PVs either using static volume provisioning or dynamic volume provisioning. The following table lists the differences between dynamic volume provisioning and static volume provisioning.

    Static volume provisioning Dynamic volume provisioning
    Resource allocation Storage resources are pre-allocated by the administrator.  Kubernetes uses Storage Classes to automatically allocate storage resources when cluster components request storage.
    Resource management Storage volumes are configured and managed by administrator. Storage volumes configuration and management is automatic.
    Use case Suited for deployments where storage requirements are stable and predictable. For example, legacy applications. Suited for deployments where storage requirements are constantly changing. For example, cloud-native applications.

    Download and upload of container images

    Container images for ITOM suites and OMT AppHub are available through Docker Hub for customers to download. Once downloaded, customers can upload these images to a container image registry that will be used for suite installations.

      Suite installation 

      The suite installation supports two installation paths: the OMT AppHub or the Helm command line interface (CLI).

      • The CLI method requires a yaml file to install a new suite. A sample values.yaml file, which includes definitions for various services and parameters, is included in your download. You will need to create your own values.yaml file based on this sample file.
      • The AppHub method allows you to configure the installation settings from the AppHub UI, and AppHub constructs this yaml file at the backend. Also, the AppHub UI includes a Yaml Editor that enables you to perform modifications to your deployment by directly inputting commands into it. This editor enables you to perform tasks not visible on the AppHub UI. 

      Choosing your path will determine how you can install other services like add-ons, perform future upgrades, and apply future patches to your deployment. For installations using the AppHub path, you will be able to use both AppHub and CLI to perform these tasks. For the CLI path, you will only be able to use CLI.

      The table below lists the differences between the two paths. You may refer to it as a guide to decide your preferred approach. 

      Installation Mode Install through OMT AppHub Install through CLI
      Requires OMT installation Yes No
      Has a user interface Yes No
      Suite installation Yes Yes
      Operations Orchestration (OO) Containerized installation Yes Yes
      Audit installation Yes Yes
      Containerized UD/UCMDB installation No Yes
      CMP FinOps capability Yes Yes
      Cloud Carbon Footprint capability Yes Yes
      Hybrid Cloud Management capability Yes Yes
      Software Asset Management capability Yes Yes
      Service Portal for Service Management capability Yes Yes
      Audit Collector capability No Yes
      Virtual Agent capability No Yes
      Perform future upgrades or apply patch with CLI Yes Yes
      Perform future upgrades or apply patch with AppHub Yes No

      The high-level steps to install OMT AppHub and one ITOM suite (such as OpenText Service Management) are as follows.

      With external Kubernetes

      1. Deploy or prepare an external Kubernetes instance.
      2. Download and unpack the OMT compressed archive.
      3. Download and unpack the Helm chart compressed archive of the ITOM suite.
      4. (Optionally) Bootstrap OMT AppHub into the external Kubernetes cluster.
      5. Create a new deployment to hold the ITOM suite.
      6. Run the Helm chart installation to install the ITOM suite using the OMT AppHub or Helm CLI.

      With embedded Kubernetes

      1. Prepare Linux systems for installation.
      2. Download and unpack the OMT compressed archive.
      3. Download and unpack the Helm chart compressed archive of the ITOM suite.
      4. Copy the bootstrap installation files to the first control plane node.
      5. Configure the installation for the control plane and worker nodes by using the install.properties file and/or installation command line options.
      6. Configure an installation options file for silent installation.
      7. On the first control plane node, start the OMT installation. This will install a complete yet empty Kubernetes cluster with selected OMT capabilities.
      8. Create a new deployment to hold the ITOM suite.
      9. Run the Helm chart installation to install the ITOM suite using the OMT AppHub or Helm CLI.

      Add-on installation

      For each new installation, the Service Management capability is mandatory, and the rest (add-on capabilities) are optional. You have the option to install all product capabilities in one go or first install some and then the others at a later time. More details on available capabilities, installation steps, and how to enable each capability will be provided in later steps when you start your installation. You can install these add-on product capabilities either by using the Helm CLI or the OMT AppHub.

      Note that currently, some capabilities can only be installed using the CLI. See the table in the Helm section of the "Suite installation approach" section above.

      Native SACM or traditional UD/UCMDB integration

      OpenText Service Management can work with Universal Discovery and CMDB (UD/UCMDB) to manage configuration items in your environment. UD/UCMDB consists of Universal CMDB and Universal Discovery. 

      UD/UCMDB ships with the following editions:

      • Classic UD/UCMDB: an executable for Windows (.exe) or Linux (.bin) installation, installed as a standalone application in a classic (non-containerized) manner
      • Containerized UD/UCMDB: a Helm charts package, installed as a standalone application

      Which edition to use depends on how you want OpenText Service Management to integrate with UD/UCMDB: through the Native SACM solution, or traditional OPB-based integration. 

      Native SACM

      This is the recommended solution. To learn more, see Get started with Native SACM. 

      • Can use either classic UD/UCMDB or containerized UD/UCMDB. 
      • Containerized UD/UCMDB supports fewer installation platforms than OpenText Service Management. For information about supported platforms, see Deploy Native SACM. 
      • For the Native SACM support matrix, see the integration support matrix. 

      Traditional OPB-based integration (deprecated)

      This integration is deprecated and might be obsoleted in a future release.

      • Must use classic UD/UCMDB.
      • For the support matrix of this integration, see the integration support matrix. 

      To learn more, see Integrate with external UCMDB.  

      Classic OO or OO Containerized

      Think about which edition of Operations Orchestration (OO) you will need.  

      • If you want to use any Cloud Management capabilities, which are Design and Deploy (DND), Cloud Management Platform (CMP) FinOps, and Image Aggregation (IA), you must install OO Containerized.
      • If you don't need any Cloud Management capabilities, you can install either classic OO or OO Containerized.

      To-Do list

      The following is a checklist of tasks that you need to perform in different phases: before the installation, during the installation, and after the installation. 

      Pre-installation phase 

      Once you have decided on installation options such as deployment platform, and product capabilities, refer to the appropriate sizing guide and support matrix and prepare the required hardware resources.

      Installation phase

      Environment type Task
      Embedded K8s Deploy the suite with the embedded K8s.
      EKS Deploy the suite on AWS.
      AKS Deploy the suite on Azure.
      OpenShift Deploy the suite on OpenShift.
      GCP

      Deploy the suite on GCP.
      External K8s (BYOK)

      Deploy on any BYOK platforms that are CNCF certified.

      Post-installation phase

      Task No. Task Doc links
      1 Set up the tenant Set up a tenant
      2 Administer the suite Configure the suite in Suite Administration
      3 Set up SAML Set up SAML authentication
      4 Tune the system Perform post-installation tuning
      5 Implementation Implementation checklist
